custom.usage:
import { WebServer } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";
const { WebServer } = require("@cloudcamp/aws-runtime");
from cloudcamp.aws_runtime import WebServer
using Cloudcamp.Aws.Runtime;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.WebServer;

docs.remarks:
WebServer runs any web application behing a load balancers as docker containers. For example, this runs a web application as a single container exposed on port 8080:

new WebServer(app.production, "prod-web", {
   dockerfile: "../Dockerfile",
   port: 8080
});
new WebServer(app.production, "prod-web", {
   dockerfile: "../Dockerfile",
   port: 8080
});
WebServer(app.production, "prod-web",
    dockerfile="../Dockerfile",
    port=8080
)
new WebServer(app.Production, "prod-web", new WebServerProps {
    Dockerfile = "../Dockerfile",
    Port = 8080
});
new WebServer(app.getProduction(), "prod-web", new WebServerProps.Builder()
        .dockerfile("../Dockerfile")
        .port(8080).build());
docs.summary: A scalable web server running one or more docker containers behind a load balancer.

custom.remarks: During initialization you can configure: Custom domains, SSL, machine configuration, health checks and the default number of instances.

docs.remarks:
Examples:

To use your own domain and serve traffic via SSL, use the domain and ssl properties:

new WebServer(app.production, "prod", {
   dockerfile: "../Dockerfile",
   domain: "example.com",
   ssl: true
});
new WebServer(app.production, "prod", {
   dockerfile: "../Dockerfile",
   domain: "example.com",
   ssl: true
});
WebServer(app.production, "prod",
    dockerfile="../Dockerfile",
    domain="example.com",
    ssl=True
)
new WebServer(app.Production, "prod", new WebServerProps {
    Dockerfile = "../Dockerfile",
    Domain = "example.com",
    Ssl = true
});
new WebServer(app.getProduction(), "prod", new WebServerProps.Builder()
        .dockerfile("../Dockerfile")
        .domain("example.com")
        .ssl(true).build());

See domain:create and cert:create for more information on setting up domains/SSL.
